facts.text: Appellant Basudev Hazra was leaseholder of tolls at public ferry Sadar Ghat on river Damodar, lease period August 14, 1963 to August 13, 1966 (Ex. 2).

On November 30, 1964, Matiar Rahman Mandal filed complaint against appellant before Sadar Sub-Divisional Officer (Judicial), Burdwan, alleging appellant illegally realised 20 nP. per cart from cultivators driving carts across dry bed of river.
Matter reported to S.D.O. who directed enquiry, infuriating appellant.
On November 29, 1964, appellant realised double toll amount; on protest and refusal by complainant, threatened with violence.
Magistrate convicted appellant under ss. 23 and 24 of Bengal Ferries Act, 1885; sentenced to fine Rs. 10/- under s.23 (SI 10 days default) and Rs. 20/- under s.24 (SI 20 days default).
Appellant challenged conviction on revision before Sessions Judge; Additional Sessions Judge, Burdwan referred to Calcutta High Court recommending acquittal.
Appellant's defence: complainant's party used landing stage and path constructed/repaired by him, liable to pay usual toll.
Complainant's case: Did not use facilities provided by lessee, used own path; lessee demanded toll despite this.

Trial Magistrate found: (i) appellant realised toll in excess of scheduled 20 ps. per cart, including from persons not using ferry; (ii) complainant did not avail ferry, crossed sandy bed, but 40 ps. per cart realised.
Calcutta High Court on September 13, 1967: Accepted reference for acquittal under s.23; rejected for s.24, upheld conviction as realisation of 40 ps. fell within s.24.
Appellant secured special leave to appeal under Art. 136 of Constitution.
Evidence showed appellant delayed prosecution witnesses without due cause in crossing river.

legal_issues.text: Whether realisation of 40 ps. per cart from persons not using the ferry (crossing dry/sandy bed) falls within mischief of s.24 of Bengal Ferries Act, 1885, which penalises taking more than lawful toll.

petitioner_arguments.text: Realisation of 40 ps. per cart from those who do not use the ferry cannot as a matter of law fall within s.24; unless someone actually uses ferry, charges realised even if demanded as toll do not attract s.24.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Section 24 Bengal Ferries Act; s.5 definition of ferry; possibly extortion under IPC

petitioner_arguments.text: Pathway and landing stage belonged to lessee, entitled to collect toll.

court_reasoning.text: S.24 does not speak only of taking excess toll from those using ferry; covers illegal demand under pretext of toll when not legally claimable; protects against harassment by lessee in privileged position.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Whether person obliged to pay toll or not immaterial if demanded/received as toll pretext when not due; attracts s.24 to suppress mischief.

court_reasoning.text: S.5 definition of ferry not exhaustive, does not control interpretation of s.24.
court_reasoning.key_observation: S.24 designed to protect crossing persons from excess demands and delays.

court_reasoning.text: Whether case of extortion under IPC irrelevant; if covered by s.24, punishable thereunder; IPC liability does not exclude s.24.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Appellant's defence supports that amount demanded as toll, unlawful demand.

court_reasoning.text: Excluding such cases would restrict s.24 effectiveness, defeat object; no grave miscarriage of justice warranting Art.136 interference.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Evidence supports findings; appeal lacks merit.

holdings.text: S.24 Bengal Ferries Act applies to demanding/receiving more than lawful toll or under pretext of toll when not legally due, even from non-users of ferry.

statutes_cited.name: Bengal Ferries Act, 1885
statutes_cited.relevance: S.24 penalises lessee taking more than lawful toll or delaying without cause; conviction under s.24 upheld, s.23 acquitted.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Special leave granted; discretionary power exercised sparingly, no interference as no miscarriage of justice.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Penal Code
statutes_cited.relevance: Mentioned re extortion, but irrelevant as s.24 applies independently.

outcome.summary: Appeal against High Court upholding conviction under s.24 Bengal Ferries Act dismissed; conviction and sentence stand; no interference under Art.136.

key_quotes.text: "Every such lessee or other person as aforesaid asking or taking more than the lawful toll... shall be punished with fine which may extend to one hundred rupees."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Text of s.24, central to interpretation.

key_quotes.text: "This section seems to have been designed... to protect the persons crossing the river against harassment and abuse of the privileged position which the lessee... occupies."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains purpose and broad scope of s.24.

key_quotes.text: "Art. 136... confers a discretionary power on this Court to be exercised sparingly... where grave miscarriage of justice has resulted."
key_quotes.speaker: court
